TopicTitle: A cause of multiple copies of a part. (Linux and possibly Windows)

Articles.Content:
I had a problem with multiple copies of the same part. Lots of multiple copies, and it was the whole set of parts form a Mod which had been working OK in Windows.

The first part of the solution was when I checked the PartDatabase.cfg file in the KSP root folder (same place as the executable). The multiple copies were there. The file is a list of parts, and the key is in this bit (for each part).

PART

{

url = Corvus/Parts/Corvus_Nose/Corvus_Nose

That URL is the sub-folder in GameData and the multiple copies were there. I should have looked sooner, because that first element of the URL was in the "hidden" format. It's used by both Linux and Windows. In bath cases, the file manager program defaults to not showing folder and file names if the format ".filename"

So, for some reason, I had been trying to install a Mod. The Linux archive manager had been failing to extract the file properly, and had put the contents in a hidden folder. I hadn't checked for this, tried to extract the files again, and got them in another hidden folder. And it seems that Windows zipfile handling had worked OK.

When KSP loaded, it neatly loaded all the hidden-subfolder contents (we could argue about that: that's something that could be used in abusive ways) and there were the multiple copies.

There don't look to be any flaws in the actual extracted content. I was able to copy-and-paste the correct subfolder from one of the hidden folders. The rest was deleted, and no problems.

Since I had no problem with the same compressed file under Windows I hesitate to blame the data compression.

It was version 0.5.4. of the KAS mod, which cas things such as winches and fuel-transfer pipes, and elements that can be used for construction in the field.

It seems possible to me that a hidden subfolder might be created if something goes wrong with the extraction of a set of files. So it's worth checking for that. I don't know if the Windows equivalent extracts to such a local hidden subfolder. I have a feeling it uses the Temp folder, which means it dodges the whole multiple-copy problem.

Hmmm... Thanx for this...I think I just recently noticed a few part dupes in the editor, and was wondering how that happened...Havent even had the chance to investigate it though...So I'll check this...I also switch between Windoze and Linux, and access my Gamedata folder in both OS's, also installing mods from both OSs in the same KSP install folder.

I'm not sure how you're using the same GameData folder in both, but there certainly shouldn't be any problem with the file formats and folder structures. Windows does have Shortcuts, which are the same sort of idea as symlinks in Unix, so I think I can see where to start looking. I've certainly not had any problems reading and writing to ntfs partitions from Linux.

I don't see any great advantage in using a Windows version when you have Linux, but there may be a couple of gotchas. Have you tried KSP with Wine?

No, not PLAYING using the same KSP install folder, just unzipping mod folders, pruning parts, editing .cfgs in either Windoze or Linux...I use the Windows Search to find duplicate files in the Gamedata...Havent gotten a similar function in Linux to work...Also, sometimes I'm in Windows surfing the web or forums, and just easier to install a mod I just downloaded in Windows, than to reboot into Linux to do it...Stuff like that...

I HAVE noticed I've been able to copy the complete Linux Gamedata folder, over to a Windows KSP install folder, and the game seems to play fine in Windows...Havent tried the reverse...

Edited October 23, 2015 by Stone Blue

I HAVE noticed I've been able to copy the complete Linux Gamedata folder, over to a Windows KSP install folder, and the game seems to play fine in Windows...Havent tried the reverse...

I haven't done a complete folder, but I've done that Windows to Linux with subfolders, no problem.

Assume you had an install set up to use a different Tech Tree. GameData-A uses the standard tech tree, and a link to that could be in GameData-B. You could certainly do that for the Squad subfolder. I'd likely also do it for Module Manager and one or two others

Is it worth the hassle? Disk space is cheap.
